Srinivasa Ramanujan (22 December 1887 ‚Äì 26 April 1920) was an Indian mathematician and autodidact. Though he had almost no formal training in pure mathematics, he made extraordinary contributions to mathematical analysis, number theory, infinite series, and continued fractions. Ramanujan initially developed his own mathematical research in isolation; it was quickly recognized by Indian mathematicians. When his skills became obvious and known to the wider mathematical community, centered in Europe at the time, he began a partnership with the English mathematician G. H. Hardy. The Cambridge professor realized that Ramanujan had rediscovered previously known theorems in addition to producing new ones.

+J!NXTER The mindset of science is based around it. Test until you find the definitive truth. Humans are not born skeptics and are malleable individuals. We didn't learn to doubt until contradictions appear to us. Science is built around solid evidence which means that scientists are by profession, inclined to be skeptical and it shows when they come upon competing theories. But when the goal is to find the objective truth, the very foundation of a scientific experiment is to eliminate all elements that would result in an inconclusive answer. The process of math focuses on patterns of discovery based upon a numerical system. The different formulas generated by mathematicians are likewise checked and proven by other mathematicians. But since the source of these formulas are born from the human mind, it tends to have no real explanation for many other than divine inspiration. Maybe it is the way they are formed or what was done to reach the conclusion, but the subject of math is a lot like art. You have to pursue the pattern in order to reach an answer. +Polina Z Ralte That is a way of thinking that really interferes with what theories actually are, which are steps towards other discoveries. Theories are tested and proven based on evidence and in most cases, while they are not definitive, they are what set the standards for things to come. Modern science is built upon scientists knowing nothing about the subject and everything we have now is transitional. In other words, theories may not be definitive, but they are substantially more than JUST theories. In science, there are no such thing as laws because there are always potential discoveries that may change or build upon existing theories. While treating science as unwavering is wrong it should be noted that science in general is a culmination of what humans have learned from the world, not hearsay made of cockamamie ideas.

The 12th century indian mathematician Bhaskara, considered division by 0 and said that a number divided by 0 was INFINITE. This is because if we divide a number by a very small number the answer is very large. For example 7 divided by a tenth is 70, and by a hundredth is 700. This bizarre concept of infinity does NOT conform to the usual rules of arithmetic and is not a number in the usual sense.
It's not a number EVER. It's an idea, an idea of something that has no end.

+Kiyamlol He is a British guy in chappie lol. However as you said it's more likely he will be picked for the roles he has done in the past, the same with most actors. Actors are often defined by and therefore picked for roles they fit in the eye of the viewer. Want to portray an Indian mathematician, you pick the best/ most famous Indian Actor who seems to fit the role. Similarly if your casting for a kung fu master, your unlikely to pick a redneck from Texas, because the viewer is going to struggle to be convinced by him. I mean sure if you give him some elaborate backstory to explain it it can be done, but there are enough actors out there which fit particular roles to just find the perfect actor for the role. A lot of films are centred on these stereotypes because the viewer finds it easier to accept.

Srinivasa Ramanujan FRS (pronunciation: Listeni/ ÉriÀêniv…ëÀês…ô r…ëÀêm…ëÀên äd í…ôn/) (22 December 1887 ‚Äì 26 April 1920) was an Indian mathematician and autodidact. Though he had almost no formal training in pure mathematics, he made extraordinary contributions to mathematical analysis, number theory, infinite series, and continued fractions. Ramanujan initially developed his own mathematical research in isolation; it was quickly recognized by Indian mathematicians. When his skills became apparent to the wider mathematical community, centred in Europe at the time, he began a famous partnership with the English mathematician G. H. Hardy. He rediscovered previously known theorems in addition to producing new theorems. During his short life, Ramanujan independently compiled nearly 3,900 results (mostly identities and equations). Nearly all his claims have now been proven correct, although some were already known. He stated results that were both original and highly unconventional, such as the Ramanujan prime and the Ramanujan theta function, and these have inspired a vast amount of further research. The Ramanujan Journal, an international publication, was launched to publish work in all areas of mathematics influenced by his work. source:wiki

Man: Infinity (symbol: ‚àû) is an abstract concept describing something without any bound and is relevant in a number of fields, predominantly mathematics and physics. In mathematics, "infinity" is often treated as if it were a number (i.e., it counts or measures things: "an infinite number of terms") but it is not the same sort of number as natural or real numbers. Georg Cantor formalized many ideas related to infinity and infinite sets during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. In the theory he developed, there are infinite sets of different sizes (called cardinalities).[1] For example, the set of integers is countably infinite, while the infinite set of real numbers is uncountable.

So glad this story is finally be told on the big screen. Ramanujan was a true genius and used that genius to make amazing discoveries for which there are still conferences on trying to figure out the almost magical insight of this man. He was self-educated by reading primarily a single book...which was a uniquely condensed yet comprehensive text of mathematical proofs Carr's A Synopsis of Elementary Results in Pure and Applied Mathematics. The text is available now on amazon, but was also able to be downloaded for free from the Internet Archive and google books a few years ago. Its a fascinating read which because it doesn't have the fluff that most modern publishers use for dubious reasons of adding unecessary heft for profit, would not bore a budding genius and allow him to reach a new potential quickly. His story really speaks to the fact that there are great people from humble backgrounds who can achieve miraculous things if they have the right education and support. I wonder how many Ramanjan's there are out there thoughout the world who have never had the opportunity to reach their potential.

replies.commentText: +Zack Barkley according to Srinivasa Ramanujam he was perceptive of such mathematical thought by the grace and blessings of goddess Namagiri.
Yes, I believe he believed she wrote mathematical truths on his tongue while he slept. He was a romantic as well as a genius.
+Zack Barkley what did ramanujan do exactly that makes him great?

+FromBoomTown You're question doesn't really make sense. Anyone who goes to a wikipedia page can find his accomplishments. They used to have a yearly conference in Chicago discussing trying to proof his many mathematical statements (often without proof). I don't know if you've studied maths to know but it sound like you have not. His formula are really out of this world using continued frations, strange exponentials...and they work, even though they are nothing like we normally use. His work has important applications in number theory which applies to crytography, and many of his formulas no doubt will only have application in the far future when we have the other sciences catch up with them. I fear you question either comes from ignorance of maths or perhaps racism since he was from Southern India which are given lower castes. When I was in India, it seemed there was a lot of racism toward the Soutern and darker skinned castes, which is a real shame since Ramanujan should be considered a national hero. He certainly has done a lot more for this world than most Brahmins or cricket players.

+Zack Barkley well I have heard white supremacists and other mathematicians malign him so I wasn't sure if his contributions were genuine or contrived by the liberal left. I am not a mathematician though I hope to be one day.

+FromBoomTown There is no way any mathematician who studied his equations would say this...they are starnge, beautiful, and seem to come from nowhere. Whole treatises are written about a a few of his formulats. He was very unconventional and mathematicians of the day and perhaps some now might think because he did not use classical proofs that it couldn't be important...but time has shown this is not the case. He made significant inroads into continued fractional representations and also divergent series, but that was only part of this work. The whole proof thing while important was somewhat blindsided by Godel work anyways, and there are whole schools of mathematical thought (intuitionist) which have some standing. As I said, the other sciences probably have a long way to go to catch up with this stuff and use it to its full potential....even with quantum physics and quantum field theory we're working with complex numbers and integral/differential geometry developed hundred years before Ramanujan. He died very young unfortunately.
He could only make do with a small slate as papers were pricey ( maybe because british rule discriminated especially against such prowess ). so step by step was difficult.

commentText: I remember reading about him in the Encyclopaedia Brittanica... A professor at Oxford received a letter, read a little of it, and then threw it in his waste basket, for he was used to getting letters from "crackpots" claiming to have solved this, or that... But he had a feeling.. so he took the letter out of the waste basket... and soon realized that it was written by a kid in a village in India, who had stumbled upon a math textbook, taught himself from it, and then.. invented the rest... but what he invented was stuff already discovered by great western minds such as Gauss and Euler and others.. not knowing of what they had done... so he invited him to Oxford to fill in the blanks... In time, he hated his eccentricities, namely his Hindu fatalism - if he got sick, refused to see a doctor, calling it karma, or whatever... Once he was in a cab with a professor who looked at a license plate and said casuaaly, What a boring number. And Ramanujan replied something like, Actually it is an interesting number, being prime... It was like four digits. ... I think he might have made some contribution in astrophysics.. no, not Chandreshkar, but Ramanujan... I don't know... my memory comes and goes.

Sir Srinivasa Ramanujan! The greatest Mathematician born in Erode, raised in #Madras (Chennai),When he was 11 later lent a book on advanced trigonometry and mastered this book by the age of 13 and discovered sophisticated theorems on his own. +yuva raja Ramaswamy Aiyer sent Ramanujan, with letters of introduction, to his mathematician friends in Madras.[36] Some of these friends looked at his work and gave him letters of introduction to R. Ramachandra Rao, the district collector for Nellore and the secretary of the Indian Mathematical Society.[38][39][40] Ramachandra Rao was impressed by Ramanujan's research but doubted that it was actually his own work. Ramanujan mentioned a correspondence he had with Professor Saldhana, a notable Bombay mathematician, in which Saldhana expressed a lack of understanding of his work but concluded that he was not a phoney.[41] Ramanujan's friend, C. V. Rajagopalachari, persisted with Ramachandra Rao and tried to quell any doubts over Ramanujan's academic integrity. Rao agreed to give him another chance, and he listened as Ramanujan discussed elliptic integrals, hypergeometric series, and his theory of divergent series, which Rao said ultimately "converted" him to a belief in Ramanujan's mathematical brilliance.[41] When Rao asked him what he wanted, Ramanujan replied that he needed some work and financial support. Rao consented and sent him to Madras. He continued his mathematical research with Rao's financial aid taking care of his daily needs. Ramanujan, with the help of Ramaswamy Aiyer, had his work published in the Journal of the Indian Mathematical Society

Ramanujan was a great mathematician but I don't like how this movie tries to make proof look like an irrelevant detail that only lesser mortals need. A lot of mathematics is beautiful because of the results pulled in from different areas and united to create an elegant series of logic. A lot of advanced mathematics actually involves proving extremely obvious things that all of us take for granted in answering questions like what a natural and real number are, and constructing number systems.

As much as I love Srinivasa Ramanujan, the characters look little awkward here. GH Hardy looks way older in this movie. He was 10 years older than Ramanujan but he looks like Ramanujan father's age in this movie. I would be much happier if they did Ramanujan with someone other than Dev Patel and showed Hardy less older. But still I think I'll watch this movie.

replies.commentText: +kemi7689 The problem wasn't people believing or understanding him, in math you prove stuff, and when you are that much of a genius no one understands you, the problem was people not being welcoming of him or not taking too much interest in his works. Because he was self taught, you never knew if what ever thing he was using if he saw it somewhere, if he proved it somewhere, or if it was an unproven theorem. To this day this kind of problem happens when gigantic proofs arise because of the sheer size a mistake is bound to happen, specially when referencing other proofs. So the problem was that he needed people to verify his theorems, the sheer amount of work was intimidating for anyone, and the purpose of his work was vague, well, because he only cared about pure mathematics not necessarily eventual applications. He was like fermat, but without the rubbing of eventual interesting applications on people's faces or the gloating that would at least make people want to disprove or prove him. The reason someone took really good interest was the sheer amount of obscure mathematics he referenced and how they all weirdly came together. As one guy said "if someone imagined this, it must be true" because by no other means but reality someone could have imagined something so non-intuitive. And interestingly he was an easier proof than many like him, everything he conjectured (intentionally or not) has been proven true. His work was very odd, but not as hard to prove as one would have though looking at it, which makes me thankful he existed, He was one of the people that if he had not lived we wouldn't get anything like it so soon. And pretty much all he has done is absurdly useful, it's like he invented the electrical engine in the iron age and in a way that wasn't all that hard to reproduce or verify.

+lloydgush Well said, he such a genius, guess they couldn't catch up at that time. It was like when this scientists was telling people the world was round and they didn't believe then. There probably scientists and mathematician now, people are looking at as mad with what looks like ridiculous theories to others?.... Genius are always miles, decades ahead of normal.
+kemi7689 He was beyond genius, in my opinion, at least beyond most genius in our history.

Does it really need to be explained? One of the scenes in this propaganda piece shows some Brits kicking the shit out of this migrant worker - the parallels are intentional and obvious, If you oppose unrestrained, perpetual third world migration to your home town you're a "racist" It's stupid, low-brow propaganda nonsense.

+mchurch72 Okay. But this is based on a true story, and this project has been in development for quite some time before all this recent migrant controversy. Also, those of upper classes or those that displayed exceptional talents, (such as in this case) from Britain's colonies regularly studied in England, and would return home after. It was hardly ever for permanent settlement, and never in droves of randoms unlike in the case of these migrants. It may understandably come off that way to some people, but I think the timing is coincidental. I doubt Ramanujan's story is being sold for the sole purpose of trying to create sympathizers to what is quite a different situation.
Right, but as we all know, the lefties that control hollywood and moviemaking generally will always find a way to interweave contemporary politics generally. This is one such case.
